  labs(x = "Loanable Funds", y = "Interest Rate (i)", 
       title = "Classical Loanable Funds Market", color = "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "top")








Figure 1: Classical Theory of Interest (Loanable Funds Market)








Keynes reframes interest as the reward for holding wealth in illiquid form rather than liquid form. Thus:

A fall in \(i\) increases money demand (agents prefer liquidity over bonds),
Money demand and money supply jointly determine \(i\),
Higher income shifts money demand right and raises \(i\) (via higher transactions demand).

Keynes also notes the reconciliation with the classical view via a system approach (IS–LM), as later formalized by Hicks.
Classical economists explained interest rate determination through the loanable funds market, where the interest rate adjusts to equate saving and investment. In that view (often illustrated by a supply-of-savings and demand-for-investment diagram), the interest rate is the price of funds: households’ willingness to save (defer consumption) increases with a higher interest return, while firms’ willingness to invest in new capital decreases with higher financing costs. Equilibrium occurs when \(S = I\), and at that point the interest rate balances the economy’s ex ante saving and investment. An increase in desired saving (e.g. due to higher income or thriftiness) would shift the savings supply curve rightward and drive the equilibrium interest rate down, encouraging more investment. In this classical view, interest is ultimately governed by real factors (productivity and time preference) and saving-investment behavior, not directly by the quantity of money.
Keynes’s liquidity preference theory, by contrast, emphasizes money market equilibrium. He did not deny that income affects saving and investment, but in the short run he assumed saving is mostly driven by income (via the marginal propensity to consume) rather than by the interest rate. Investment, on the other hand, depends on interest and profit expectations. In Keynes’s theory, the interest rate adjusts until money demanded = money supplied, given the level of income and money stock. For example, if income rises (more transactions), the money demand curve \(L(Y,i)\) shifts right; if the money supply is unchanged, this excess demand for money will drive up interest rates until people are content holding the available money (because higher \(i\) reduces the speculative and precautionary demand). Conversely, if the central bank increases the money supply, initially there is excess money in portfolios, so people try to rebalance by buying bonds and assets – bidding up their prices and pushing down the interest rate. Thus, in liquidity preference theory, an increase in income raises interest rates (money demand up), and an increase in money supply lowers interest rates (money supply up), ceteris paribus.
Keynes’s view can be reconciled with the classical loanable funds approach by considering interactions in both goods and money markets simultaneously. In fact, the IS-LM model (originally formulated by John Hicks in 1937 as an interpretation of Keynes) combines the two: the IS curve captures equilibrium in the goods market (where investment equals saving, or equivalently aggregate demand equals output), and the LM curve captures equilibrium in the money market (liquidity preference equals money supply). We will use IS-LM shortly to analyze Keynesian equilibrium and disequilibrium conditions. First, however, we examine Keynes’s famous concept of the liquidity trap, an extreme case of liquidity preference with profound policy implications.




Keynes’s theory of money demand begins with the recognition of three motives for holding money, expanding beyond the single transactions motive emphasized by classical economists. In classical thinking (e.g. quantity theory), people hold money only to facilitate transactions – the medium of exchange function – and any excess money would quickly be spent, rendering money neutral in its effect on the economy. Keynes acknowledged the transactions motive (holding money for routine purchases of goods and services) but also identified two additional motives arising from money’s role as a liquid store of value that pays no interest:
• Precautionary motive – holding money for unexpected contingencies or emergencies that might require quick expenditure. Even households and firms with planned budgets keep some funds in readily accessible cash or deposits as a precaution against unforeseen events (medical bills, urgent repairs, etc.). This motive implies money demand increases with the uncertainty of the environment or the need for flexibility.
• Speculative motive – holding money instead of other assets when the return on bonds or other interest-bearing assets is low, or when those assets are expected to fall in price. This is related to expectations about future interest rates. If people expect interest rates to rise (which means bond prices will fall), they may prefer to hold wealth in money now and wait for a better opportunity to buy bonds later. Money is perfectly liquid (it can be used directly for transactions and does not incur capital loss), whereas bonds and other assets carry interest but can fluctuate in value. The speculative demand for money is inversely related to the interest rate: when interest (\(i\)) is high, people are more willing to hold bonds (earning interest) and less inclined to hold idle money; but when \(i\) is low, the opportunity cost of holding money is small, so people are more inclined to keep wealth liquid in money form.



Keynes formalized these ideas in his liquidity preference theory. The demand for money can be expressed as a function \(L(Y, i)\), where \(Y\) is income and \(i\) is the interest rate. The transactions and precautionary motives imply that \(L\) increases with real income \(Y\) (higher income means more spending and a larger buffer for contingencies). The speculative motive implies that \(L\) decreases as \(i\) rises (higher interest provides a reward for parting with liquidity). In other words:
• \(\frac{\partial L}{\partial Y} > 0\): Higher income raises money demand (for transactions and safety reserves). • \(\frac{\partial L}{\partial i} < 0\): Higher interest rates reduce money demanded (as the public holds interest-bearing assets instead).
Keynes described interest rate as the reward for relinquishing liquidity. Unlike classical theory which saw interest as the reward for saving (waiting to consume), Keynes argued that at any given level of income, the interest rate adjusts to equilibrate money demand with the fixed money supply. In equilibrium, money supply \(M\) = money demand \(L(Y, i)\), and the interest rate is the “price” that brings this about. If the central bank sets a fixed nominal money supply \(M\) (and for a given price level \(P\), a fixed real money supply \(M/P\)), then the interest rate will move until money market clears.

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
At very low interest rates \(i_L\), the speculative motive dominates: agents are reluctant to hold bonds because:

Yields are too low to compensate for inconvenience and illiquidity,
They expect rates cannot go much lower (so bond prices are “too high”) and thus fear capital losses when rates rise.

Hence the liquidity preference schedule becomes horizontal: money demand becomes infinitely interest-elastic.


Code
library(ggplot2)

# Money demand - normal region
M_normal <- seq(0, 8, length.out = 50)
i_normal <- 8 - M_normal

# Liquidity trap region
M_trap <- seq(8, 12, length.out = 20)
i_trap <- rep(1.5, length(M_trap))

# Combine
df <- data.frame(
  M = c(M_normal, M_trap),
  i = c(i_normal, i_trap)
)

# Plot
ggplot(df, aes(x = M, y = i)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 1.5, color = "red",  
             linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 0.8, alpha = 0.7) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = 8, xmax = 12, ymin = 0, ymax = 1.5, 
           fill = "red", alpha = 0.15) +
  annotate("text", x = 10, y = 1.9, label = "i[L]~(trap~floor)", 
           parse = TRUE, color = "red", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = 1.5, xmax = 4.5, ymin = 4.5, ymax = 5.5,
           fill = "wheat", alpha = 0.7) +
  annotate("text", x = 3, y = 5, 
           label = "Normal region:\ndownward sloping", 
           size = 3.5) +
  labs(x = "Money Demand (M)", y = "Interest Rate (i)", 
       title = "Liquidity Preference Schedule") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 12), ylim = c(0, 9))








Figure 2: Liquidity Preference Schedule with Liquidity Trap








When liquidity preference is horizontal, an increase in money supply shifts portfolios into money balances without lowering \(i\) further. This is the canonical statement that conventional monetary policy becomes ineffective in a liquidity trap.



The major economies have faced liquidity trap conditions:

Bank of England (March 2009): Cut Bank Rate to 0.5% and launched an asset purchase programme (“QE”) to provide further monetary loosening once conventional policy was constrained.
Bank of Japan (1999–2001): Adopted a Zero Interest Rate Policy (ZIRP) in 1999 and Quantitative Easing in 2001, reflecting prolonged low-rate conditions consistent with liquidity-trap concerns.
European Central Bank (2014–2019): Introduced negative deposit facility rates in June 2014 and lowered them further (to -0.5% by 2019), reflecting attempts to relax constraints near the effective lower bound.

These episodes are best interpreted as policy responses to Keynesian concerns about weak demand at very low rates—though modern frameworks emphasize multiple transmission channels beyond the short rate (QE, forward guidance, credit policy).

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
In standard IS-LM, if the intersection occurs below potential output \(\bar{Y}\), goods demand is weak, placing downward pressure on the price level \(P\). A fall in \(P\) raises real money balances \(M/P\), shifting LM down/right, lowering \(i\), and increasing \(Y\), restoring equilibrium at \(\bar{Y}\).


Code
library(ggplot2)

# Output
Y <- seq(0, 10, length.out = 100)

# IS curve (downward sloping)
IS <- 8 - 0.6 * Y

# LM curves
LM1 <- 1 + 0.5 * Y  # Initial LM
LM2 <- 0.3 + 0.5 * Y  # LM after price fall (shifted down/right)

# Full employment output
Y_bar <- 7

# Initial equilibrium (below full employment)
Y0 <- 4.3
i0 <- 5.4

# New equilibrium (at full employment)
Y1 <- Y_bar
i1 <- 8 - 0.6 * Y1

# Plot
ggplot() +
  geom_line(aes(x = Y, y = IS), color = "blue", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_line(aes(x = Y, y = LM1), color = "red", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_line(aes(x = Y, y = LM2), color = "red", linewidth = 1.2, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = Y_bar, linetype = "dotted", color = "gray50", linewidth = 1, alpha = 0.7) +
  annotate("point", x = Y0, y = i0, size = 4, color = "black") +
  annotate("point", x = Y1, y = i1, size = 4, color = "darkgreen") +
  annotate("segment", x = Y0, y = i0, xend = Y1, yend = i1, 
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm")), 
           color = "darkgreen", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = Y_bar + 0.2, y = 0.5, label = "bar(Y)", parse = TRUE, 
           fontface = "bold", size = 4.5) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = 4.5, xmax = 6.5, ymin = 4.0, ymax = 5.0,
           fill = "lightgreen", alpha = 0.7) +
  annotate("text", x = 5.5, y = 4.5, 
           label = "Price falls →\nLM shifts right", 
           size = 3) +
  annotate("text", x = 8.5, y = 2.5, label = "IS", color = "blue", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  annotate("text", x = 9.5, y = 5.8, label = "LM(P[0])", parse = TRUE, color = "red", size = 4) +
  annotate("text", x = 9.5, y = 5.0, label = "LM'(P' < P[0])", color = "red", size = 4) +
  labs(x = "Output (Y)", y = "Interest Rate (i)", 
       title = "IS-LM: Normal Times Adjustment via Deflation") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 8))








Figure 3: IS-LM Adjustment in Normal Times (Price Deflation Restores Full Employment)





Key mechanism (Keynes effect): Deflation → higher real money → lower interest → higher investment → higher output.



In the liquidity trap, LM is horizontal at \(i_L\). The critical point: falling \(P\) stretches LM rightwards but does not shift it downwards. Therefore, the economy cannot reach \(\bar{Y}\) via the usual adjustment channel.


Code
library(ggplot2)

# Output and curves
Y <- seq(0, 10, length.out = 100)
IS <- 6 - 0.5 * Y
i_L <- 2.0
Y_bar <- 7

df <- data.frame(Y = Y, IS = IS)
Y0 <- (6 - i_L) / 0.5

ggplot(df, aes(x = Y)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IS), color = "blue", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = i_L, color = "red", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = i_L, color = "red", linewidth = 1.2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.6) +
  annotate("point", x = Y0, y = i_L, color = "red", size = 4) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = Y_bar, linetype = "dotted", color = "gray50", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = Y_bar + 0.3, y = 0.3, label = "bar(Y)", parse = TRUE, fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = min(Y0, Y_bar), xmax = max(Y0, Y_bar), ymin = 0, ymax = 5, fill = "red", alpha = 0.15) +
  annotate("text", x = 6.5, y = 3.5, label = "Output gap:\ncannot close\nvia deflation", size = 3.5) +
  labs(x = "Output (Y)", y = "Interest Rate (i)", title = "IS-LM in Liquidity Trap: Interest Rate Channel Blocked") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 6))








Figure 4: IS-LM in a Liquidity Trap (Price Adjustment Fails)





Key insight: Price adjustment mechanism broken; interest-rate channel blocked.



Because price falls do not stimulate aggregate demand, the AD curve becomes vertical in a liquidity trap. This is the stark Keynesian disequilibrium result: even flexible prices may not restore full employment if the interest-rate mechanism is blocked.


Code
library(ggplot2)

Y <- seq(0, 10, length.out = 100)
Y_bar <- 7
P_normal <- 10 - 0.8 * Y
Y_trap <- 4
P0 <- 5

df_ad <- data.frame(Y = Y, P_normal = P_normal)

ggplot(df_ad, aes(x = Y)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = P_normal), color = "blue", linewidth = 1.2, alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = Y_trap, color = "red", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = Y_bar, color = "green", linetype = "dashed", linewidth = 1.2) +
  annotate("point", x = Y_trap, y = P0, color = "red", size = 4) +
  annotate("text", x = Y_trap - 0.5, y = P0 + 0.5, label = "Stuck at Y₀", size = 3.5) +
  annotate("rect", xmin = min(Y_trap, Y_bar), xmax = max(Y_trap, Y_bar), ymin = 0, ymax = 10, fill = "red", alpha = 0.15) +
  annotate("text", x = 5.5, y = 7, label = "Output gap", size = 4, fontface = "bold", color = "darkred") +
  annotate("segment", x = Y_trap, y = 8, xend = Y_trap, yend = 2, 
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm")), color = "red", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = Y_trap + 0.5, y = 4.5, label = "P falls but\nY unchanged", color = "red", size = 3.5) +
  labs(x = "Output (Y)", y = "Price Level (P)", title = "AD-AS: Liquidity Trap Implies Vertical AD") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 10))








Figure 5: AD-AS: Vertical Aggregate Demand in Liquidity Trap








Any increase in money supply shifts LM rightwards but not downward, so the economy does not move to full-employment output. Hence conventional monetary policy cannot affect aggregate demand in a liquidity trap. This is why central banks have resorted to unconventional measures (quantitative easing, forward guidance, credit policy).

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
The classical dichotomy implies a separation between nominal and real variables: in equilibrium, money affects only prices, not output or employment. Money is neutral in the long run – doubling the money supply eventually doubles all prices and wages, with no impact on real GDP, employment, or real interest rates.



Keynes disputed the assumption of rapid, uniform nominal price adjustment, particularly in labour markets. He observed an “unevenness” in price adjustment: some prices (like wages in long-term contracts) are quite sticky or inflexible downwards, whereas others (like commodity prices or exchange rates) might be more flexible.
If nominal prices adjust unevenly, relative prices deviate from their market-clearing values for extended periods. Therefore:

Money is not neutral (at least over relevant horizons),
Dichotomy fails because money can affect real outcomes (relative prices, unemployment),
Monetary policy has real effects in the short-to-medium term due to nominal rigidities.

This line of reasoning is foundational for why modern macroeconomics treats monetary policy as potentially stabilizing in the presence of nominal rigidities—even though long-run neutrality may still hold in many models.

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
Don Patinkin argued that money provides “utility” because it facilitates transactions; thus money should enter utility functions as a quasi-good, particularly in real terms \(M/P\). This insight forms the foundation of the Pigou effect critique.



Pigou’s argument applies Patinkin’s insight against Keynes’s trap logic: if demand depends positively on real balances, falling prices increase \(M/P\), potentially shifting IS right/up and closing the demand gap.
The mechanism: - Prices fall → real money balances (\(M/P\)) rise - Households and firms feel wealthier - Consumption and investment demand increase (wealth effect) - IS curve shifts rightward - Even in a liquidity trap (with \(i_L\) fixed), the rightward IS shift can eventually intersect LM at full employment \(\bar{Y}\)
This implies the trap might be overcome by market forces alone.



Keynesians offer several rebuttals:

Quantitatively small or very slow-acting: In a deep recession or depression, people might be too pessimistic or liquidity-constrained to increase consumption just because prices are a bit lower. They might instead hoard any extra real wealth to rebuild balance sheets.
Debt-deflation dynamics: Deflation raises the real burden of debt, which can reduce debtors’ spending (counteracting Pigou). This redistributes wealth from borrowers (who curtail spending) to creditors (who may not increase spending much), possibly resulting in a net drop in demand.
Destabilizing expectations: Sustained deflation can worsen expectations – if people expect prices to keep falling, they might postpone purchases (the opposite of Pigou’s assumption), a dynamic observed in Japan’s deflationary period.
Institutional constraints: Prices and wages cannot fall indefinitely due to institutional and psychological limits. Central banks actively fight deflation for these reasons—for example, the ECB’s commitment to a positive inflation target (near 2%) is partly to avoid falling into a deflationary trap where any Pigou effect would be too feeble and slow.




All that said, the Pigou effect remains an important theoretical critique because it highlights a channel (wealth-consumption) that Keynes’s original model left out. In later developments of Keynesian theory, economists like Patinkin integrated real balances into the analysis, which helped reconcile some classical and Keynesian views. They concluded that if prices are perfectly flexible and wages adjust (so no other frictions), then even a liquidity trap would eventually be resolved by sufficient deflation raising real money balances – thus restoring long-run neutrality of money even if short-run non-neutrality is severe. However, if there are other constraints (like the inability of nominal interest to go below zero, or institutional and psychological limits to how much and how fast prices can fall), then the economy can suffer prolonged departures from full employment – just as Keynes asserted.

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
The following points capture the essence of Keynes’s monetary economics in the context of lecture notes on Monetary Economics EC3014:

In a monetary economy, Walras’ Law does not imply Say’s Law – excess demand for money can co-exist with excess supply of goods.
The money market is exceptional – money’s nominal price does not adjust, supply is exogenous, and close substitutes are limited.
Usually, interest rates and/or the price level can restore equilibrium, but sluggish adjustment can generate prolonged unemployment.
In a liquidity trap, money demand is infinitely interest-elastic – LM becomes horizontal and conventional monetary policy loses power.
In that case, price changes may not raise aggregate demand – AD becomes vertical in the trap logic.
Say’s Law breaks down in a monetary economy – Keynes showed that excess saving can translate into hoarding money, destroying aggregate demand and causing unemployment.
Pigou and Patinkin offer a critique – rising real balances under deflation can potentially stimulate demand (Pigou effect), but this mechanism may be weak or slow in practice.
Even outside traps, Keynes argues money is not neutral because price adjustment is uneven; the classical dichotomy fails.
Policy implications are profound – when the interest-rate channel is blocked (liquidity trap), policymakers must rely on unconventional tools (quantitative easing, fiscal policy, forward guidance) to restore demand.

title: Keynes’s Theory of Money
text:
Keynes’s theory of money brought money demand and liquidity preference to the forefront of macroeconomics, fundamentally altering how we analyze interest rates and output. Unlike the classical one-dimensional view of money (for transactions only), Keynes identified multiple motives for holding money – transactions, precautionary, and speculative – which together imply that money demand depends on both income and interest rates. The interest rate, in turn, is viewed as the price that equilibrates the supply and demand for money (liquidity), rather than purely the reward for saving as in classical theory.
We explored the concept of the liquidity trap, Keynes’s most dramatic departure from classical thinking. In a liquidity trap, extremely low interest rates lead to a horizontal money demand curve – additional money gets hoarded rather than spent. The liquidity trap highlights how an economy can get stuck with inadequate demand, zero interest rates, and even deflation, rendering conventional monetary policy ineffective. The IS-LM disequilibrium analysis showed that in such a scenario, the usual self-correcting mechanisms (interest rate adjustment and price-level adjustment) may fail to restore full employment. This underlines Keynes’s broader point that money is not neutral, especially during economic downturns.
The experiences of Japan’s lost decade and the post-2008 global slump demonstrate the importance of Keynes’s insights: when money’s usual role as a lubricator of the economy breaks down, proactive measures are needed to avoid long-term stagnation. At the same time, the debate between Keynesian and classical views (as epitomized by the Pigou effect discussion) highlights that the long-run interaction between money and the real economy is complex. Overall, Keynes’s work ensures that economists and policymakers treat money not as a mere veil, but as a fundamental part of the economy’s structure that can shape macroeconomic outcomes.

title: Topic 4 - Indicative Answers
text:
Part (a)





From the production function, the marginal product of labour is: \[\frac{\partial Y}{\partial N} = \frac{160}{2\sqrt{N}} = \frac{80}{\sqrt{N}}\]
When firms maximise profit, they hire labour until \(MPN = \theta\). Therefore: \[\theta = \frac{80}{\sqrt{N}}\] \[\sqrt{N} = \frac{80}{\theta}\] \[N = \frac{6400}{\theta^2}\]
This matches the given labour demand equation, confirming consistency. ✓


Setting \(N^S = N^D\): \[100\theta = \frac{6400}{\theta^2}\] \[100\theta^3 = 6400\] \[\theta^3 = 64\] \[\theta = 4\]
Therefore: \(N = 100 \times 4 = 400\)
Substituting into the production function: \[Y = 160\sqrt{400} = 160 \times 20 = 3200\]



From the QTM: \(P = \frac{M}{kY}\)
With \(M_0 = 32000\) and \(k = 2\): \[P_0 = \frac{32000}{2 \times 3200} = \frac{32000}{6400} = 5\]
The money wage is: \[W_0 = \theta \times P_0 = 4 \times 5 = 20\]



With \(M_1 = 48000\): \[P_1 = \frac{48000}{2 \times 3200} = \frac{48000}{6400} = 7.5\]
In long-run equilibrium, the labour market remains at its natural level regardless of money supply changes. Therefore: \[\theta = 4, \quad N = 400, \quad Y = 3200 \text{ (unchanged)}\] \[W_1 = 4 \times 7.5 = 30\]



Yes, the model exhibits dichotomy and neutrality of money. Real variables (\(\theta\), \(N\), \(Y\)) are determined solely by production technology and labour supply preferences, independent of the money supply. A 50% increase in \(M\) (from 32000 to 48000) causes exactly proportional increases in nominal variables (prices and wages double from \(5 \to 7.5\), \(20 \to 30\)) but leaves all real variables unchanged. This demonstrates classical neutrality: in the long run, money is a veil over the real economy.














Part (a)





With workers using \(P_0 = 5\) as the reference price: \[N^S = 100\frac{W'}{5} = 20W'\]
Setting \(N^S = N^D\): \[20W' = \frac{6400}{(\theta')^2} = \frac{6400(P')^2}{(W')^2}\] \[(W')^3 = \frac{6400(P')^2}{20} = 320(P')^2\] \[P' = \frac{\sqrt{(W')^3}}{\sqrt{320}} = \frac{(W')^{3/2}}{\sqrt{320}} = \frac{\sqrt{80}(W')^{3/2}}{160}\]


From the labour supply: \(N' = 20W'\)
Plugging into production function: \[Y' = 160\sqrt{20W'}\]
From the QTM with \(M_1 = 48000\): \[P' = \frac{M_1}{kY'} = \frac{48000}{2 \times 160\sqrt{20W'}} = \frac{150}{\sqrt{20W'}}\]



Equating the two expressions for \(P'\): \[\frac{\sqrt{80}(W')^{3/2}}{160} = \frac{150}{\sqrt{20W'}}\]
Solving: \[(W')^2 = \frac{150^2 \times 160^2}{80 \times 20} = 600\] \[W' \approx 24.49\]
Therefore: \[N' = 20 \times 24.49 = 489.8\] \[Y' = 160\sqrt{489.8} \approx 3545.7\] \[P' = \frac{48000}{2 \times 3545.7} \approx 6.76\] \[\theta' = \frac{W'}{P'} = \frac{24.49}{6.76} \approx 3.62\]
Note that \(\theta' = 3.62 < 4 = \theta_0\), but \(W' = 24.49 > 20 = W_0\). Workers perceive a wage rise even though the real wage has fallen!



Verifying labour market equilibrium at \(\theta' = 3.62\): \[N^S = 20 \times 24.49 = 489.8\] \[N^D = \frac{6400}{(3.62)^2} \approx 488.5 \approx N^S\] ✓
Labour market clears in the short run.



Friedman’s key insight: Money illusion creates short-run non-neutrality. Workers observe \(W' > W_0\) and perceive a real wage increase even though \(\theta' < \theta_0\). This illusion causes labour supply to expand far beyond its natural level, pulling down the real wage and increasing both employment and output above their long-run levels.
Short run: Monetary expansion stimulates employment (\(N' = 489.8 > 400\)) and output (\(Y' = 3545.7 > 3200\)) because workers are fooled about inflation.
Long run: When workers eventually recognise that \(P'\) has risen more than \(W'\), they realise their real wage has fallen. Labour supply contracts back to its natural level, \(N\) returns to 400, \(Y\) reverts to 3200, and \(\theta\) returns to 4.
This supports Friedman’s argument that monetary policy has temporary real effects in the short run but is neutral in the long run—the lag between actual and perceived inflation is crucial to short-run monetary non-neutrality. The Phillips curve is downward-sloping in the short run (trade-off between inflation and unemployment) but vertical in the long run (no permanent trade-off).














Part (a)





From the dynamic QTM: \[\pi = g_M - g_Y = 3\% - 1\% = 2\%\]
From the Fisher equation: \[i = r + \pi = 2\% + 2\% = 4\%\]


When \(g_M\) accelerates from \(3\%\) to \(6\%\):
Short Run:

(i) Growth rate of output temporarily rises above \(1\%\) (to ~\(1.5\%\)). The increase in money growth stimulates employment and output via money illusion. Workers see nominal wages rising faster than expected and supply more labour, pushing output above trend.
(ii) Rate of inflation rises but lags the increase in money growth (to ~\(3-4\%\), less than the full \(5\%\)). Initially, prices adjust slowly while the monetary expansion feeds into employment growth. The inflation gap (\(g_M - \pi > 0\)) creates the real stimulus.
(iii) Nominal interest rate initially falls below \(4\%\) (to ~\(3\%\)). Real rates are pushed down as inflation expectations lag, and the output boom creates downward pressure on interest rates.
(iv) Real interest rate falls temporarily below \(2\%\) into negative territory. The excess money supply and output expansion compress real returns.

Long Run:

(i) Growth rate of output returns to \(1\%\). Once workers and firms perceive the true inflation, they adjust expectations. Labour supply reverts to its natural level, and output growth returns to its trend determined by labour force growth and technology.
(ii) Rate of inflation settles at \(\pi = g_M - g_Y = 6\% - 1\% = 5\%\). The full monetary impulse translates to inflation once expectations fully adjust.
(iii) Nominal interest rate rises to \(i = r + \pi = 2\% + 5\% = 7\%\). Higher inflation raises nominal rates accordingly.
(iv) Real interest rate returns to \(2\%\). The real rate is determined by real fundamentals (time preferences, productivity) independent of monetary growth. Monetary changes affect only nominal magnitudes in the long run.

title: Topic 4 - Indicative Answers
text:
Part (a)





From the production function, the marginal product of labour is: \[\frac{\partial Y}{\partial N} = \frac{160}{2\sqrt{N}} = \frac{80}{\sqrt{N}}\]
When firms maximise profit, they hire labour until \(MPN = \theta\). Therefore: \[\theta = \frac{80}{\sqrt{N}}\] \[\sqrt{N} = \frac{80}{\theta}\] \[N = \frac{6400}{\theta^2}\]
This matches the given labour demand equation, confirming consistency. ✓


Setting \(N^S = N^D\): \[100\theta = \frac{6400}{\theta^2}\] \[100\theta^3 = 6400\] \[\theta^3 = 64\] \[\theta = 4\]
Therefore: \(N = 100 \times 4 = 400\)
Substituting into the production function: \[Y = 160\sqrt{400} = 160 \times 20 = 3200\]



From the QTM: \(P = \frac{M}{kY}\)
With \(M_0 = 32000\) and \(k = 2\): \[P_0 = \frac{32000}{2 \times 3200} = \frac{32000}{6400} = 5\]
The money wage is: \[W_0 = \theta \times P_0 = 4 \times 5 = 20\]



With \(M_1 = 48000\): \[P_1 = \frac{48000}{2 \times 3200} = \frac{48000}{6400} = 7.5\]
In long-run equilibrium, the labour market remains at its natural level regardless of money supply changes. Therefore: \[\theta = 4, \quad N = 400, \quad Y = 3200 \text{ (unchanged)}\] \[W_1 = 4 \times 7.5 = 30\]



Yes, the model exhibits dichotomy and neutrality of money. Real variables (\(\theta\), \(N\), \(Y\)) are determined solely by production technology and labour supply preferences, independent of the money supply. A 50% increase in \(M\) (from 32000 to 48000) causes exactly proportional increases in nominal variables (prices and wages double from \(5 \to 7.5\), \(20 \to 30\)) but leaves all real variables unchanged. This demonstrates classical neutrality: in the long run, money is a veil over the real economy.

title: Topic 4 - Indicative Answers
text:
Part (a)





With workers using \(P_0 = 5\) as the reference price: \[N^S = 100\frac{W'}{5} = 20W'\]
Setting \(N^S = N^D\): \[20W' = \frac{6400}{(\theta')^2} = \frac{6400(P')^2}{(W')^2}\] \[(W')^3 = \frac{6400(P')^2}{20} = 320(P')^2\] \[P' = \frac{\sqrt{(W')^3}}{\sqrt{320}} = \frac{(W')^{3/2}}{\sqrt{320}} = \frac{\sqrt{80}(W')^{3/2}}{160}\]


From the labour supply: \(N' = 20W'\)
Plugging into production function: \[Y' = 160\sqrt{20W'}\]
From the QTM with \(M_1 = 48000\): \[P' = \frac{M_1}{kY'} = \frac{48000}{2 \times 160\sqrt{20W'}} = \frac{150}{\sqrt{20W'}}\]



Equating the two expressions for \(P'\): \[\frac{\sqrt{80}(W')^{3/2}}{160} = \frac{150}{\sqrt{20W'}}\]
Solving: \[(W')^2 = \frac{150^2 \times 160^2}{80 \times 20} = 600\] \[W' \approx 24.49\]
Therefore: \[N' = 20 \times 24.49 = 489.8\] \[Y' = 160\sqrt{489.8} \approx 3545.7\] \[P' = \frac{48000}{2 \times 3545.7} \approx 6.76\] \[\theta' = \frac{W'}{P'} = \frac{24.49}{6.76} \approx 3.62\]
Note that \(\theta' = 3.62 < 4 = \theta_0\), but \(W' = 24.49 > 20 = W_0\). Workers perceive a wage rise even though the real wage has fallen!



Verifying labour market equilibrium at \(\theta' = 3.62\): \[N^S = 20 \times 24.49 = 489.8\] \[N^D = \frac{6400}{(3.62)^2} \approx 488.5 \approx N^S\] ✓
Labour market clears in the short run.



Friedman’s key insight: Money illusion creates short-run non-neutrality. Workers observe \(W' > W_0\) and perceive a real wage increase even though \(\theta' < \theta_0\). This illusion causes labour supply to expand far beyond its natural level, pulling down the real wage and increasing both employment and output above their long-run levels.
Short run: Monetary expansion stimulates employment (\(N' = 489.8 > 400\)) and output (\(Y' = 3545.7 > 3200\)) because workers are fooled about inflation.
Long run: When workers eventually recognise that \(P'\) has risen more than \(W'\), they realise their real wage has fallen. Labour supply contracts back to its natural level, \(N\) returns to 400, \(Y\) reverts to 3200, and \(\theta\) returns to 4.
This supports Friedman’s argument that monetary policy has temporary real effects in the short run but is neutral in the long run—the lag between actual and perceived inflation is crucial to short-run monetary non-neutrality. The Phillips curve is downward-sloping in the short run (trade-off between inflation and unemployment) but vertical in the long run (no permanent trade-off).

title: Topic 4 - Indicative Answers
text:
Part (a)





From the dynamic QTM: \[\pi = g_M - g_Y = 3\% - 1\% = 2\%\]
From the Fisher equation: \[i = r + \pi = 2\% + 2\% = 4\%\]


When \(g_M\) accelerates from \(3\%\) to \(6\%\):
Short Run:

(i) Growth rate of output temporarily rises above \(1\%\) (to ~\(1.5\%\)). The increase in money growth stimulates employment and output via money illusion. Workers see nominal wages rising faster than expected and supply more labour, pushing output above trend.
(ii) Rate of inflation rises but lags the increase in money growth (to ~\(3-4\%\), less than the full \(5\%\)). Initially, prices adjust slowly while the monetary expansion feeds into employment growth. The inflation gap (\(g_M - \pi > 0\)) creates the real stimulus.
(iii) Nominal interest rate initially falls below \(4\%\) (to ~\(3\%\)). Real rates are pushed down as inflation expectations lag, and the output boom creates downward pressure on interest rates.
(iv) Real interest rate falls temporarily below \(2\%\) into negative territory. The excess money supply and output expansion compress real returns.

Long Run:

(i) Growth rate of output returns to \(1\%\). Once workers and firms perceive the true inflation, they adjust expectations. Labour supply reverts to its natural level, and output growth returns to its trend determined by labour force growth and technology.
(ii) Rate of inflation settles at \(\pi = g_M - g_Y = 6\% - 1\% = 5\%\). The full monetary impulse translates to inflation once expectations fully adjust.
(iii) Nominal interest rate rises to \(i = r + \pi = 2\% + 5\% = 7\%\). Higher inflation raises nominal rates accordingly.
(iv) Real interest rate returns to \(2\%\). The real rate is determined by real fundamentals (time preferences, productivity) independent of monetary growth. Monetary changes affect only nominal magnitudes in the long run.

title: Topic 5 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





Adaptive Expectations: Backward-Looking
The first claim is true. Adaptive expectations are formed by using the observed historical time path of a variable to project its future expected value. This approach is inherently backward-looking because it ignores the possibility that a variable’s trajectory might suddenly change if one of its underlying determinants changes.
For example, if inflation has been 2% for several years, adaptive expectations would predict future inflation around 2%, even if the central bank has just announced a permanent increase in money growth targeting 5% inflation. The model would only gradually adjust expectations upward as inflation actually rises over time.
Rational Expectations: Forward-Looking
The second claim is best understood in reverse: rational expectations naturally lead to forward-looking forecasting behaviour. A rational agent recognises that variables are interdependent and uses a model describing mutual inter-relationships between variables to predict future values of endogenous variables, using all available information about future exogenous variables.
Under rational expectations, whenever an agent is informed that an exogenous variable will deviate from its historical trend, they can correctly forecast that the endogenous variable they’re interested in will also deviate from its own historical trend. This ability to forecast sudden deviations from observed patterns makes rational expectations forward-looking.
Example: Predictable vs Unpredictable Money Changes

Predictable money increase: Under adaptive expectations, workers don’t anticipate the wage inflation coming from increased money supply. They’re surprised by higher nominal wages, work more (thinking real wages rose), and output expands temporarily.
Under rational expectations, if workers know the central bank has announced a permanent money increase, they predict prices and wages will rise proportionally. They don’t increase labour supply, output remains unchanged—money is neutral even in the short run.

This illustrates the key difference: rational expectations allow agents to anticipate and respond to announced future changes, making the economy respond differently than adaptive expectations would suggest.













Tip





The Lucas Aggregate Supply Equation
The Lucas AS equation expresses a relationship between deviations of output from its full-employment level and deviations of the price level from its expected value:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \kappa(P_t - E_{t-1}P_t)\]
In words: output deviates from potential only when actual prices differ from expected prices—that is, when agents face price surprises.
Connection to Friedman’s Monetary Policy Analysis
The Lucas AS equation explains Friedman’s argument about short-run monetary effects through the following mechanism:

An unpredictable increase in money causes prices to rise unexpectedly
Workers and firms observe higher nominal wages/prices but expect lower inflation
Misperceiving real wages as higher, workers supply more labour
Output temporarily expands above potential
Once expectations adjust and workers realise prices are higher, output returns to \(Y^*\)

This captures Friedman’s key insight: monetary policy affects real variables (output and employment) only when unpredictable, creating a temporary Phillips curve trade-off in the short run.
Beyond Friedman: The Volatility Effect
However, the Lucas version based on rational expectations reveals something Friedman’s analysis didn’t emphasise: the magnitude of the output effect depends on monetary volatility.
Lucas showed that the coefficient \(\kappa\) is inversely proportional to the volatility of monetary policy. When monetary policy is highly volatile: - Agents realise that price fluctuations are largely driven by unpredictable money changes - They discount price surprises in making supply decisions - Price surprises have smaller effects on output
Thus, the Lucas AS equation not only explains Friedman’s short-run effects but also shows that more volatile monetary policy paradoxically produces smaller real effects—a distinctly New Classical insight.













Tip





The Lucas AS Equation and Monetary Shocks
In the New Classical model, the Lucas AS equation states:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \kappa(P_t - E_{t-1}P_t)\]
where output deviates from potential only when actual prices exceed expected prices.
The Relationship Between Money and Price Surprises
With rational expectations, the price surprise is related to the money surprise by:
\[P_t - E_{t-1}P_t = \frac{1}{1+\kappa}(M_t - E_{t-1}M_t)\]
Combining these gives the relationship between unpredictable monetary shocks and output:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \frac{\kappa}{1+\kappa}(M_t - E_{t-1}M_t)\]
Note that the coefficient \(\frac{\kappa}{1+\kappa}\) decreases as \(\kappa\) increases—and Lucas proved that \(\kappa\) is inversely proportional to monetary volatility.
Intuitive Explanation
When monetary policy is highly volatile:

Agents experience frequent, large, unpredictable fluctuations in the money supply and prices
They realise that most price changes are driven by monetary shocks, not real productivity changes
When they observe a price increase, rational agents ask: “Is this real inflation or just monetary noise?”
Recognising it’s likely monetary noise, they discount the price signal and don’t adjust supply decisions much
The measured \(\kappa\) (sensitivity of output to price surprises) becomes very small
Result: Output remains closer to potential despite frequent price surprises

Conversely, when monetary policy is predictable and stable:

Agents see price changes as more likely reflecting real demand shifts
Price surprises are taken as genuine signals about real conditions
Agents respond more strongly to price changes
\(\kappa\) is larger, and unpredictable monetary changes have bigger output effects

The Paradox
This creates an apparent paradox: money affects output only by being unpredictable, yet the more unpredictable money is, the smaller its real effects become.
The resolution is that rational agents learn the volatility characteristics of monetary policy and adjust their attention to different types of signals. In a highly volatile monetary environment, price signals become noisier and less informative about real conditions, so agents respond less to them.













Tip





The Problem: Systematic Policy is Predictable
In standard New Classical theory, a systematic monetary policy rule—where money supply is deliberately set according to some formula—is predictable by rational agents. They form expectations based on this anticipated money supply, rendering the policy unable to affect real variables. Monetary policy cannot systematically stabilise the economy.
The Solution: Exploiting Information Asymmetry
However, a special combination of circumstances allows systematic stabilisation:
(i) Technology shocks with persistence: Productivity shocks whose effects persist over multiple periods (not just the current period). A negative productivity shock reduces output not only immediately but through reduced capital productivity in subsequent periods.
(ii) Information asymmetry: The central bank observes these technology shocks as they arise, but the public learns about them only after their effects have dissipated or become much smaller.
How Systematic Policy Can Work
Holding money constant, a recessionary technology shock would: - Reduce output in period \(t\) (when shock occurs) - Continue damaging output in periods \(t+1\), \(t+2\), etc. (persistence effect)
But if the central bank, having observed the shock, conditions future money supply over several periods on the shock’s magnitude, it can eliminate the persistence effect:
Example: Following a recessionary productivity shock, 1. Central bank observes the shock in period \(t\) (public doesn’t yet know its magnitude) 2. Central bank increases money supply in periods \(t+1\), \(t+2\), etc. 3. This increases aggregate demand and raises the price level 4. Since public doesn’t yet know the magnitude of the supply shock, they don’t perfectly predict the money increase 5. The resulting price surprise stimulates employment and output, offsetting the negative supply-side effect 6. By quantitatively linking money injections to observed shock size, the central bank can precisely neutralise output persistence
The Role of the Policy Rule
Crucially, the policy follows a known rule: “If we observe a productivity shock of size \(X\), we will expand money by \(Y\).”

Rational agents know this rule, so they can predict it ex-ante
But they lack current information on shock magnitude, so they cannot predict the exact money expansion that will result
The policy is “systematic” (not arbitrary) yet remains unpredictable to the public

Key Insight
This works because the central bank has a comparative information advantage. It observes current shocks faster than the public; it uses this advantage to inject money that will be surprising (but predictable in principle if you knew the shock size). The public, knowing the policy rule but not current shock magnitudes, cannot perfectly predict the resulting money supply, leaving room for systematic policy to have real effects.
Implications
This explains why central banks focus on real-time shock monitoring (employment data, inflation, financial conditions) and why forward guidance is only effective when it conveys new information the public doesn’t have—not merely statements of predictable rules.

Tip





Adaptive Expectations: Backward-Looking
The first claim is true. Adaptive expectations are formed by using the observed historical time path of a variable to project its future expected value. This approach is inherently backward-looking because it ignores the possibility that a variable’s trajectory might suddenly change if one of its underlying determinants changes.
For example, if inflation has been 2% for several years, adaptive expectations would predict future inflation around 2%, even if the central bank has just announced a permanent increase in money growth targeting 5% inflation. The model would only gradually adjust expectations upward as inflation actually rises over time.
Rational Expectations: Forward-Looking
The second claim is best understood in reverse: rational expectations naturally lead to forward-looking forecasting behaviour. A rational agent recognises that variables are interdependent and uses a model describing mutual inter-relationships between variables to predict future values of endogenous variables, using all available information about future exogenous variables.
Under rational expectations, whenever an agent is informed that an exogenous variable will deviate from its historical trend, they can correctly forecast that the endogenous variable they’re interested in will also deviate from its own historical trend. This ability to forecast sudden deviations from observed patterns makes rational expectations forward-looking.
Example: Predictable vs Unpredictable Money Changes

Predictable money increase: Under adaptive expectations, workers don’t anticipate the wage inflation coming from increased money supply. They’re surprised by higher nominal wages, work more (thinking real wages rose), and output expands temporarily.
Under rational expectations, if workers know the central bank has announced a permanent money increase, they predict prices and wages will rise proportionally. They don’t increase labour supply, output remains unchanged—money is neutral even in the short run.

This illustrates the key difference: rational expectations allow agents to anticipate and respond to announced future changes, making the economy respond differently than adaptive expectations would suggest.

title: Topic 5 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





The Lucas Aggregate Supply Equation
The Lucas AS equation expresses a relationship between deviations of output from its full-employment level and deviations of the price level from its expected value:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \kappa(P_t - E_{t-1}P_t)\]
In words: output deviates from potential only when actual prices differ from expected prices—that is, when agents face price surprises.
Connection to Friedman’s Monetary Policy Analysis
The Lucas AS equation explains Friedman’s argument about short-run monetary effects through the following mechanism:

An unpredictable increase in money causes prices to rise unexpectedly
Workers and firms observe higher nominal wages/prices but expect lower inflation
Misperceiving real wages as higher, workers supply more labour
Output temporarily expands above potential
Once expectations adjust and workers realise prices are higher, output returns to \(Y^*\)

This captures Friedman’s key insight: monetary policy affects real variables (output and employment) only when unpredictable, creating a temporary Phillips curve trade-off in the short run.
Beyond Friedman: The Volatility Effect
However, the Lucas version based on rational expectations reveals something Friedman’s analysis didn’t emphasise: the magnitude of the output effect depends on monetary volatility.
Lucas showed that the coefficient \(\kappa\) is inversely proportional to the volatility of monetary policy. When monetary policy is highly volatile: - Agents realise that price fluctuations are largely driven by unpredictable money changes - They discount price surprises in making supply decisions - Price surprises have smaller effects on output
Thus, the Lucas AS equation not only explains Friedman’s short-run effects but also shows that more volatile monetary policy paradoxically produces smaller real effects—a distinctly New Classical insight.

title: Topic 5 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





The Lucas AS Equation and Monetary Shocks
In the New Classical model, the Lucas AS equation states:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \kappa(P_t - E_{t-1}P_t)\]
where output deviates from potential only when actual prices exceed expected prices.
The Relationship Between Money and Price Surprises
With rational expectations, the price surprise is related to the money surprise by:
\[P_t - E_{t-1}P_t = \frac{1}{1+\kappa}(M_t - E_{t-1}M_t)\]
Combining these gives the relationship between unpredictable monetary shocks and output:
\[Y_t - Y^* = \frac{\kappa}{1+\kappa}(M_t - E_{t-1}M_t)\]
Note that the coefficient \(\frac{\kappa}{1+\kappa}\) decreases as \(\kappa\) increases—and Lucas proved that \(\kappa\) is inversely proportional to monetary volatility.
Intuitive Explanation
When monetary policy is highly volatile:

Agents experience frequent, large, unpredictable fluctuations in the money supply and prices
They realise that most price changes are driven by monetary shocks, not real productivity changes
When they observe a price increase, rational agents ask: “Is this real inflation or just monetary noise?”
Recognising it’s likely monetary noise, they discount the price signal and don’t adjust supply decisions much
The measured \(\kappa\) (sensitivity of output to price surprises) becomes very small
Result: Output remains closer to potential despite frequent price surprises

Conversely, when monetary policy is predictable and stable:

Agents see price changes as more likely reflecting real demand shifts
Price surprises are taken as genuine signals about real conditions
Agents respond more strongly to price changes
\(\kappa\) is larger, and unpredictable monetary changes have bigger output effects

The Paradox
This creates an apparent paradox: money affects output only by being unpredictable, yet the more unpredictable money is, the smaller its real effects become.
The resolution is that rational agents learn the volatility characteristics of monetary policy and adjust their attention to different types of signals. In a highly volatile monetary environment, price signals become noisier and less informative about real conditions, so agents respond less to them.

title: Topic 5 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





The Problem: Systematic Policy is Predictable
In standard New Classical theory, a systematic monetary policy rule—where money supply is deliberately set according to some formula—is predictable by rational agents. They form expectations based on this anticipated money supply, rendering the policy unable to affect real variables. Monetary policy cannot systematically stabilise the economy.
The Solution: Exploiting Information Asymmetry
However, a special combination of circumstances allows systematic stabilisation:
(i) Technology shocks with persistence: Productivity shocks whose effects persist over multiple periods (not just the current period). A negative productivity shock reduces output not only immediately but through reduced capital productivity in subsequent periods.
(ii) Information asymmetry: The central bank observes these technology shocks as they arise, but the public learns about them only after their effects have dissipated or become much smaller.
How Systematic Policy Can Work
Holding money constant, a recessionary technology shock would: - Reduce output in period \(t\) (when shock occurs) - Continue damaging output in periods \(t+1\), \(t+2\), etc. (persistence effect)
But if the central bank, having observed the shock, conditions future money supply over several periods on the shock’s magnitude, it can eliminate the persistence effect:
Example: Following a recessionary productivity shock, 1. Central bank observes the shock in period \(t\) (public doesn’t yet know its magnitude) 2. Central bank increases money supply in periods \(t+1\), \(t+2\), etc. 3. This increases aggregate demand and raises the price level 4. Since public doesn’t yet know the magnitude of the supply shock, they don’t perfectly predict the money increase 5. The resulting price surprise stimulates employment and output, offsetting the negative supply-side effect 6. By quantitatively linking money injections to observed shock size, the central bank can precisely neutralise output persistence
The Role of the Policy Rule
Crucially, the policy follows a known rule: “If we observe a productivity shock of size \(X\), we will expand money by \(Y\).”

Rational agents know this rule, so they can predict it ex-ante
But they lack current information on shock magnitude, so they cannot predict the exact money expansion that will result
The policy is “systematic” (not arbitrary) yet remains unpredictable to the public

Key Insight
This works because the central bank has a comparative information advantage. It observes current shocks faster than the public; it uses this advantage to inject money that will be surprising (but predictable in principle if you knew the shock size). The public, knowing the policy rule but not current shock magnitudes, cannot perfectly predict the resulting money supply, leaving room for systematic policy to have real effects.
Implications
This explains why central banks focus on real-time shock monitoring (employment data, inflation, financial conditions) and why forward guidance is only effective when it conveys new information the public doesn’t have—not merely statements of predictable rules.

title: Topic 6 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





The Central Bank’s Loss Function
The central bank has a loss function that reflects its preferences over inflation and output:
\[L = \frac{a}{2}\pi^2 + \frac{b}{2}(Y - Y^T)^2\]
where: - \(\pi\) is inflation - \(Y\) is national income - \(Y^T\) is the CB’s desired level of national income - \(a, b\) reflect the CB’s aversion to inflation and output shortfalls, respectively - \(Y^* = Y^T + \lambda\) where \(Y^*\) is the natural level of output - \(\lambda > 0\) reflects the CB’s preference for income to exceed its natural level (output bias)
Scenario: Public Expects \(\pi = \frac{bκλ}{a}\)
If the CB accommodates this expectation, then from the Lucas AS equation: \[Y = Y^* \text{ (no surprise inflation, so } Y - Y^* = 0\text{)}\]
The loss from the real side: \(\frac{b\lambda^2}{2}\) (output is \(\lambda\) below desired level)
The loss from the inflation side: \(\frac{a}{2}\left(\frac{bκλ}{a}\right)^2 = \frac{bκ^2λ^2}{2a}\)
Total loss under accommodation: \[L = \frac{bλ^2}{2}\left[\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]\]
Alternative: Setting \(\pi = 0\) (Surprise Deflation)
If the CB sets \(\pi = 0\) despite the public expecting \(\pi = \frac{bκλ}{a}\):
From the Lucas AS equation, the price surprise causes output to deviate from potential: \[Y - Y^* = -κ\frac{bκλ}{a}\]
Since \(Y^T = Y^* - \lambda\), the output gap becomes: \[Y - Y^T = -κ\frac{bκλ}{a} + \lambda = -κ\frac{bκ^2λ}{a} + \lambda = λ\left[-\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]\]
The loss from the real side is now much larger: \[L_{\text{real}} = \frac{b}{2}\left[κ\frac{bκλ}{a} + λ\right]^2 = \frac{bλ^2}{2}\left[\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]^2\]
The inflation loss is zero: \(L_{\text{inflation}} = 0\)
Total loss under surprise deflation: \[L = \frac{bλ^2}{2}\left[\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]^2\]
Why Accommodation is Preferred
Since \(\left[\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]^2 > \left[\frac{bκ^2}{a} + 1\right]\), the loss from implementing zero inflation exceeds the loss from accommodating expected inflation.
Key Insight: The Inflation Bias Paradox
Even though the CB has no intention to surprise the public with inflation, it chooses to allow inflation at the expected level because:

The CB has an output target (\(Y^T\)) above the natural rate of output
The public, knowing this, expects accommodating inflation
Disappointing these expectations causes a severe recession that exceeds the inflation costs
The CB prefers accepting expected inflation over the real losses from surprising the public with deflation

This is the essence of time-inconsistency and the inflation bias problem: the CB’s ex-post incentive to accommodate expected inflation conflicts with its ex-ante desire to commit to low inflation. This creates a credibility problem that generates inflation bias in equilibrium.













Tip





The High-Inflation Country Problem
Countries with persistently high inflation often have central banks pursuing excessive monetary growth to achieve real sector objectives. This causes balance-of-payments deficits against low-inflation countries. Under floating exchange rates, the high-inflation currency depreciates, reflecting the difference in inflation rates.
The Fixed Exchange Rate Solution
One approach for a high-inflation country to reduce inflation is to unilaterally fix its exchange rate against a low-inflation anchor currency. Once fixed, the money supply can no longer be set independently—the country must match the anchor currency’s inflation rate to maintain the peg. By surrendering monetary autonomy, the CB signals commitment to low inflation.
Problems with Fixed Exchange Rates:
(i) Weak Commitment Signal
Fixing the exchange rate is not the most obvious or direct way to signal commitment to low inflation. Other mechanisms might more clearly demonstrate policy resolve without restricting policy flexibility.
(ii) Recurring Balance-of-Payments Deficits
If the fixed rate is set too low (too many units of local currency per anchor currency unit), the economy experiences recurring trade deficits. These deficits steadily deplete the central bank’s foreign exchange reserves, which cannot be replenished if monetary growth is constrained. Eventually, reserve depletion forces either devaluation or regime abandonment.
(iii) Loss of Monetary Autonomy During Shocks
When recessionary technology or demand shocks hit the economy, the CB may want to expand the money supply to stabilise domestic output. But the fixed rate peg prevents this, forcing the economy to bear the full burden of adjustment through price and wage deflation—a costly process.
(iv) Speculative Attacks
If markets suspect the peg is unsustainable (due to depleting reserves or political pressure to abandon it), they may engage in speculative attacks—selling the currency en masse to force devaluation. These attacks can be self-fulfilling, destroying reserves and forcing the very devaluation speculators expected.
Alternative Credibility Mechanisms:
(i) Adopting Policy Rules Rather Than Discretion
Instead of relying on discretionary decisions, the CB can commit to a transparent rule—e.g., “the money supply grows at 2% annually” or “inflation must stay within a 1-3% band.” Rules constrain the CB’s ability to pursue short-term output objectives and make policy predictable. However, rules limit flexibility during genuine emergencies.
(ii) Appointing a Conservative, Inflation-Hawk Central Banker
Credibility can be strengthened by appointing a CB governor known to be strongly committed to price stability and skeptical of inflation. If the CB leader has a public reputation as an inflation-hawk, markets and the public expect low inflation regardless of political pressure. Examples include Paul Volcker (US Fed) or the Bundesbank leadership.
(iii) Performance-Based Compensation and Incentive Schemes
Add personal financial rewards and penalties to CB officials’ compensation based on inflation outcomes. For example, senior CB managers receive bonuses if inflation stays below target but face penalties if it exceeds target. This aligns personal incentives with low-inflation objectives, counteracting bureaucratic or political biases toward expansionary policy. It makes the commitment credible because officials’ own financial interests depend on delivering low inflation.
Comparative Effectiveness
These mechanisms address the time-inconsistency problem differently: - Rules eliminate discretion ex-post - Conservative leadership creates strong ex-ante reputation and expectations of resistance to inflation - Performance incentives align individual incentives with institutional objectives, making officials directly accountable
The most credible approach typically combines multiple mechanisms: clear rules, conservative leadership, transparency, and performance accountability.

title: Topic 7 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





Problem 1: Central Banks Control the Monetary Base, Not the Money Supply
The fundamental issue is that central banks only directly control the monetary base (\(M_0\))—cash in circulation plus bank reserves. However, conventional monetary aggregates like \(M_1\) and \(M_2\) also include demand deposits and other bank liabilities created by the commercial banking sector, not the central bank.
The relationship between the monetary base and broader money aggregates depends on the money multiplier, which is determined by: - Commercial banks’ reserve requirements - Banks’ reserve management decisions (which vary over time) - The public’s preferences for cash vs deposits
When banks hold excess reserves or reduce lending, the money multiplier contracts, meaning the CB cannot reliably control the broader money supply even if it controls the base. This became especially problematic during financial crises when banks hoarded reserves and the money multiplier collapsed.
Problem 2: Money Demand is Unstable
The second problem contradicts a key assumption of the Quantity Theory of Money: that the demand for money is a stable, predictable function of nominal income.
In reality, money demand shifted significantly due to: - Financial innovation: Development of money market mutual funds, sweep accounts, and other near-money instruments that allowed the public to minimize cash holdings - Changing payment technologies: Credit cards, electronic funds transfers, and later digital payments reduced the need to hold transaction balances - Deregulation: Removal of deposit interest rate ceilings allowed competition, shifting funds between deposits and other financial assets
These shifts meant that targeting a particular growth rate for the money supply did not reliably control inflation or output. For example, if the CB targeted \(M_1\) growth at 5%, but money demand shifted inward due to financial innovation, the actual growth in monetary liquidity would be much less, potentially causing economic contraction despite the CB “hitting” its money growth target.
The Combined Effect: Loss of Control
Together, these two problems meant that: 1. The CB could not reliably control the money supply (only the base) 2. Even if it could, controlling money growth didn’t reliably control inflation (because money demand was unstable)
This motivated the shift toward interest rate targeting as the primary policy instrument, which offers more direct control over financial conditions and is less dependent on the stability of money demand or the money multiplier.













Tip





Point 1: Risk of Deflation
If the central bank targets zero inflation, there is only downside risk of deflation. In practice, inflation fluctuates around any target due to shocks and forecasting errors. With a zero target:

Inflation might temporarily fall to \(-1\%\), \(-2\%\), or lower
Once deflation begins, it can be self-reinforcing: expectations of falling prices cause households and firms to delay spending, further reducing demand and pushing prices down
Deflation creates the zero lower bound problem: nominal interest rates cannot fall below zero, limiting the CB’s ability to stimulate the economy
In a deflationary episode, real interest rates become too high even when nominal rates are zero, making borrowing expensive and investment unattractive

Historical example: Japan’s “Lost Decade” (1990s) saw deflation that made monetary policy ineffective despite near-zero nominal rates.
Point 2: The Zero Lower Bound and Interest Rates
Related to the deflation risk is the constraint on monetary policy transmission. If the CB targets zero inflation:

The equilibrium real interest rate must be achieved through nominal rates close to zero
When shocks hit, the CB has little room to cut rates further
The nominal interest rate hits the zero lower bound, preventing real rate cuts
Monetary policy becomes powerless when the economy most needs stimulus

With a positive inflation target (e.g., 2%), the CB has a buffer. When it needs to cut the nominal rate to stimulate, there’s room before hitting zero. For example, if inflation is 2% and the natural real rate is 2%, the CB can set the nominal rate at 4% (= 2% + 2%), leaving room to cut rates during recessions.
Point 3: The Wage Adjustment Mechanism
A critical but indirect mechanism is that moderate inflation allows real wages to fall without nominal wage cuts.
In recessions with high unemployment, there is downward pressure on real wages. But: - Nominal wage cuts are politically unpopular and resisted by workers - Labour contracts often have downward rigidity in nominal wages - If nominal wages cannot fall but inflation erodes the real value, real wages adjust
With positive inflation (say 2%): - A worker’s nominal wage stays at $50,000 but prices rise 2% - Real wage falls from \(50,000/\)P_0$ to \(50,000/\)P_1$ - This real adjustment allows labour markets to clear during downturns
With zero inflation target: - If real wages must fall to clear the labour market, firms must negotiate nominal wage cuts - Workers resist, unemployment persists - The economy cannot efficiently adjust to shocks
This is particularly important during periods of high unemployment when downward pressure on real wages would normally help restore labour market equilibrium.
Summary of Three Problems

Deflation risk → monetary policy becomes ineffective (zero lower bound)
Interest rate constraint → less room to stimulate during recessions
Wage rigidity → real wage adjustment becomes harder, prolonging unemployment

Most central banks target 2% inflation as a compromise: high enough to provide a buffer against deflation and interest rate constraints, yet low enough to maintain price stability.













Tip





The Primary Instrument: The Policy (Base) Interest Rate
The policy rate (also called the base rate or overnight rate) is the interest rate at which the central bank lends short-term funds—typically overnight—to commercial banks. Major central banks (Federal Reserve, ECB, Bank of England, etc.) set this rate as their primary policy instrument.
The Three Main Transmission Channels
Changes in the policy rate affect inflation through three distinct channels:


This is the gradual transmission through the financial system:

Interbank markets: When the CB raises the policy rate, banks paying higher overnight rates pass increased costs through the interbank lending market
Money market rates: Rates on commercial paper, certificates of deposit, and other money market instruments rise
Bank lending rates: Banks increase rates on mortgages, business loans, and consumer credit
Firm and household decisions: Higher borrowing costs cause:

Firms to cut investment (returns lower relative to borrowing cost)
Households to reduce consumption (especially discretionary spending and home purchases)

Goods and labour markets: Reduced spending decreases demand for goods and labour
Wages and prices: Lower labour demand reduces wage growth; reduced goods demand reduces price growth

Effect on inflation: Slower growth in wages and prices → lower inflation



This works through central bank communication and expectations:

CB signals intent: When the CB raises the policy rate, it signals that it intends to bring inflation down
Forward guidance: The CB may explicitly state that rates will remain high until inflation targets are met
Wage and price setter expectations: Workers and firms, believing inflation will fall, moderate their own wage and price demands
Immediate effect: Even before spending contracts significantly, inflation expectations fall because wage and price setters anticipate lower inflation ahead
Self-fulfilling: As workers accept lower nominal wage growth and firms set lower prices (expecting lower future inflation), inflation actually falls faster

Effect on inflation: Faster reduction in inflation through expectation management and forward guidance



This works through international financial flows:

Higher domestic rates: The CB raises the policy rate
Capital attraction: Higher returns attract foreign investment seeking yield
Currency appreciation: Increased foreign demand for the domestic currency causes it to appreciate
Lower import prices: An appreciated currency makes foreign goods cheaper in domestic terms (e.g., if the dollar appreciates, US importers pay fewer dollars for foreign goods)
Reduced inflation: Cheaper imports directly lower consumer price indices and reduce inflationary pressure from import costs
Competitiveness effect: Appreciated currency also makes domestic exports more expensive abroad, reducing external demand and further dampening inflation

Effect on inflation: Through lower import prices and reduced external demand

title: Topic 7 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





Problem 1: Central Banks Control the Monetary Base, Not the Money Supply
The fundamental issue is that central banks only directly control the monetary base (\(M_0\))—cash in circulation plus bank reserves. However, conventional monetary aggregates like \(M_1\) and \(M_2\) also include demand deposits and other bank liabilities created by the commercial banking sector, not the central bank.
The relationship between the monetary base and broader money aggregates depends on the money multiplier, which is determined by: - Commercial banks’ reserve requirements - Banks’ reserve management decisions (which vary over time) - The public’s preferences for cash vs deposits
When banks hold excess reserves or reduce lending, the money multiplier contracts, meaning the CB cannot reliably control the broader money supply even if it controls the base. This became especially problematic during financial crises when banks hoarded reserves and the money multiplier collapsed.
Problem 2: Money Demand is Unstable
The second problem contradicts a key assumption of the Quantity Theory of Money: that the demand for money is a stable, predictable function of nominal income.
In reality, money demand shifted significantly due to: - Financial innovation: Development of money market mutual funds, sweep accounts, and other near-money instruments that allowed the public to minimize cash holdings - Changing payment technologies: Credit cards, electronic funds transfers, and later digital payments reduced the need to hold transaction balances - Deregulation: Removal of deposit interest rate ceilings allowed competition, shifting funds between deposits and other financial assets
These shifts meant that targeting a particular growth rate for the money supply did not reliably control inflation or output. For example, if the CB targeted \(M_1\) growth at 5%, but money demand shifted inward due to financial innovation, the actual growth in monetary liquidity would be much less, potentially causing economic contraction despite the CB “hitting” its money growth target.
The Combined Effect: Loss of Control
Together, these two problems meant that: 1. The CB could not reliably control the money supply (only the base) 2. Even if it could, controlling money growth didn’t reliably control inflation (because money demand was unstable)
This motivated the shift toward interest rate targeting as the primary policy instrument, which offers more direct control over financial conditions and is less dependent on the stability of money demand or the money multiplier.

title: Topic 7 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





Point 1: Risk of Deflation
If the central bank targets zero inflation, there is only downside risk of deflation. In practice, inflation fluctuates around any target due to shocks and forecasting errors. With a zero target:

Inflation might temporarily fall to \(-1\%\), \(-2\%\), or lower
Once deflation begins, it can be self-reinforcing: expectations of falling prices cause households and firms to delay spending, further reducing demand and pushing prices down
Deflation creates the zero lower bound problem: nominal interest rates cannot fall below zero, limiting the CB’s ability to stimulate the economy
In a deflationary episode, real interest rates become too high even when nominal rates are zero, making borrowing expensive and investment unattractive

Historical example: Japan’s “Lost Decade” (1990s) saw deflation that made monetary policy ineffective despite near-zero nominal rates.
Point 2: The Zero Lower Bound and Interest Rates
Related to the deflation risk is the constraint on monetary policy transmission. If the CB targets zero inflation:

The equilibrium real interest rate must be achieved through nominal rates close to zero
When shocks hit, the CB has little room to cut rates further
The nominal interest rate hits the zero lower bound, preventing real rate cuts
Monetary policy becomes powerless when the economy most needs stimulus

With a positive inflation target (e.g., 2%), the CB has a buffer. When it needs to cut the nominal rate to stimulate, there’s room before hitting zero. For example, if inflation is 2% and the natural real rate is 2%, the CB can set the nominal rate at 4% (= 2% + 2%), leaving room to cut rates during recessions.
Point 3: The Wage Adjustment Mechanism
A critical but indirect mechanism is that moderate inflation allows real wages to fall without nominal wage cuts.
In recessions with high unemployment, there is downward pressure on real wages. But: - Nominal wage cuts are politically unpopular and resisted by workers - Labour contracts often have downward rigidity in nominal wages - If nominal wages cannot fall but inflation erodes the real value, real wages adjust
With positive inflation (say 2%): - A worker’s nominal wage stays at $50,000 but prices rise 2% - Real wage falls from \(50,000/\)P_0$ to \(50,000/\)P_1$ - This real adjustment allows labour markets to clear during downturns
With zero inflation target: - If real wages must fall to clear the labour market, firms must negotiate nominal wage cuts - Workers resist, unemployment persists - The economy cannot efficiently adjust to shocks
This is particularly important during periods of high unemployment when downward pressure on real wages would normally help restore labour market equilibrium.
Summary of Three Problems

Deflation risk → monetary policy becomes ineffective (zero lower bound)
Interest rate constraint → less room to stimulate during recessions
Wage rigidity → real wage adjustment becomes harder, prolonging unemployment

Most central banks target 2% inflation as a compromise: high enough to provide a buffer against deflation and interest rate constraints, yet low enough to maintain price stability.

title: Topic 7 - Indicative Answers
text:
Tip





The Primary Instrument: The Policy (Base) Interest Rate
The policy rate (also called the base rate or overnight rate) is the interest rate at which the central bank lends short-term funds—typically overnight—to commercial banks. Major central banks (Federal Reserve, ECB, Bank of England, etc.) set this rate as their primary policy instrument.
The Three Main Transmission Channels
Changes in the policy rate affect inflation through three distinct channels:


This is the gradual transmission through the financial system:

Interbank markets: When the CB raises the policy rate, banks paying higher overnight rates pass increased costs through the interbank lending market
Money market rates: Rates on commercial paper, certificates of deposit, and other money market instruments rise
Bank lending rates: Banks increase rates on mortgages, business loans, and consumer credit
Firm and household decisions: Higher borrowing costs cause:

Firms to cut investment (returns lower relative to borrowing cost)
Households to reduce consumption (especially discretionary spending and home purchases)

Goods and labour markets: Reduced spending decreases demand for goods and labour
Wages and prices: Lower labour demand reduces wage growth; reduced goods demand reduces price growth

Effect on inflation: Slower growth in wages and prices → lower inflation



This works through central bank communication and expectations:

CB signals intent: When the CB raises the policy rate, it signals that it intends to bring inflation down
Forward guidance: The CB may explicitly state that rates will remain high until inflation targets are met
Wage and price setter expectations: Workers and firms, believing inflation will fall, moderate their own wage and price demands
Immediate effect: Even before spending contracts significantly, inflation expectations fall because wage and price setters anticipate lower inflation ahead
Self-fulfilling: As workers accept lower nominal wage growth and firms set lower prices (expecting lower future inflation), inflation actually falls faster

Effect on inflation: Faster reduction in inflation through expectation management and forward guidance



This works through international financial flows:

Higher domestic rates: The CB raises the policy rate
Capital attraction: Higher returns attract foreign investment seeking yield
Currency appreciation: Increased foreign demand for the domestic currency causes it to appreciate
Lower import prices: An appreciated currency makes foreign goods cheaper in domestic terms (e.g., if the dollar appreciates, US importers pay fewer dollars for foreign goods)
Reduced inflation: Cheaper imports directly lower consumer price indices and reduce inflationary pressure from import costs
Competitiveness effect: Appreciated currency also makes domestic exports more expensive abroad, reducing external demand and further dampening inflation

Effect on inflation: Through lower import prices and reduced external demand

Diagram: Monetary Policy Transmission Channels
